title:
Counter-Rotation and Slow Precession in Aligned Eccentric Nuclear Disks
  due to Gravitational Wave Recoil Kicks
authors: Jane C. Bright, Tatsuya Akiba, Ann-Marie Madigan
abstract:
The M31 nucleus contains a supermassive black hole embedded in a massive
stellar disk of apsidally-aligned eccentric orbits. It has recently been shown
that this disk is slowly precessing at a rate consistent with zero. Here we
demonstrate using N-body methods that apsidally-aligned eccentric disks can
form with a significant (~0.5) fraction of orbits counter-rotating as the
result of a gravitational wave recoil kick of merging supermassive black holes.
Higher amplitude kicks map to a larger retrograde fraction in the surrounding
stellar population which in turns results in slow precession. We furthermore
show that disks with significant counter-rotation are more stable (that is,
apsidal-alignment is most pronounced and long lasting), more eccentric, and
have the highest rates of stars entering the black hole's tidal disruption
radius
